Full text of "Winchester College, 1836-1906 : a register"

See other formats

M  -  ■i-r-;: 


M= 


^< 


Keppel-Jones. 

No.   b:bd   I 


^^.  f^,y 


WINCHESTER    COLLEGE 

1836-1906 


WINCHESTEE    COLLEGE 

1836-1906 
A    EEGISTEE 

EDITED 

ON   BEHALF  OF  THE  WARDEN  AND  FELLOWS  OF 
THE  COLLEGE 

BY 

JOHN    BANNEEMAN   WAINEWRIGHT 


Mn 


WINCHESTER 
P.   AND   G.   WELLS 

1907 


V 


o 


^^ 


DIS  MANIBUS 

C.  W.  H. 

SOLIUS  HUIUS  OPUSCULI  AUCTORIS 

REDACTOR  IMPAR 

SIMUL  ET 

MATRI  ALMAE  DILEOTISSIMAE 

FILIUS   INDIGNUS 

FRATRIBUSQUE  DESIDERATTISSIMIS 

FRATERCULUS  HUMILIS 

BEATAEQUE  FUNDATORIS  ANIMAE 

SERVUS  HAUD  IMMEMOR 

J.  B.  W. 


PKEFACE. 

This  book  owes  its  existence  to  the  late  Mr.  Clifford  Wyndham 
Holgate's  bequest  to  the  Warden  and  Fellows  of  Winchester  College 
of  the  copyright  of  his  "  Winchester  Commoners,  1836-1890,"  and  of 
the  further  material  which  he  had  collected  for  a  second  edition,  and 
to  the  acceptance  of  the  said  bequest  by  the  legatees. 

The  further  material  above  mentioned  consisted  of  the  following  : — 

(a)  A  considerable  number  of  corrections  and  additions  made  by 
Mr.  Holgate  in  an  interleaved  copy  of  his  book ;  this  copy  was  given 
by  him  to  Mr.  Herbert  Chitty,  who  has  from  time  to  time  noted 
further  addenda  and  corrigenda. 

(h)  A  manuscript  list  of  scholars  admitted  between  January,  1836, 
and  the  end  of  1854.  This  list  (though  in  a  good  many  cases  it  does 
not  give  the  parentage  of  the  scholars,  and  in  seventeen  cases  between 
1836  and  1851  gives  nothing  but  their  names  with  dates  and  places 
of  birth)  is  fairly  full  down  to  1851  ;  from  1852  to  the  end  of  1854 
the  information  it  supplies  is  very  scanty. 

(c)  A  similar  manuscript  list  of  scholars  admitted  between  Short 
Half,  1869,  and  the  end  of  1890.  This  list  gives  in  most  cases  the 
date  of  birth  and  the  name  and  address  of  a  parent  or  guardian,  but 
in  very  few  cases  are  any- biographical  particulars  attached. 

{d)  A  manuscript  list  of  the  names  of  scholars  and  commoners 
admitted  between  the  beginning  of  Common  Time,  1891,  and  the  end 
of  Common  Time,  1901,  in  most  cases  with  the  date  of  birth  and 
name  and  address  of  parent  or  guardian,  but  in  no  case  with  any 
biographical  details. 

In  supplementing  and  correcting  the  material  placed  in  my  hands, 
I  have  obtained  much  valuable  assistance  from  Mr.  Francis  Brodie, 
Dr.   Teale,   Mr.   W.   H.   H.   Bird,  Mr.   Herbert  Chitty,  Mr.  G.  W. 


vi  Preface. 

Ricketts,  and  others  too  numerous  to  mention,  to  all  of  whom  I  am 
sincerely  grateful,  as  well  as  from  "  A  Roll  of  Names  and  Addresses  of 
Old  Wykehamists,"  edited  by  Mr.  G.  W.  Ricketts  in  1903,  and  again  in 
1906  ;  Mr,  Kirby's  "  Winchester  Scholars,"  published  in  1888  ;  and 
"Annals  of  Culver  House,"  compiled  by  Mr.  A.  W.  Oyler  and  pub- 
lished in  1905,  a  copy  of  which  last  book  was  generously  presented  to 
me  by  the  compiler.  To  Mr.  E.  T.  Cook  I  am  indebted  for  kindly 
looking  through  the  proof-sheets  and  for  valuable  suggestions  and 
corrections.  I  have  tried  to  make  the  book  as  accurate  a  record  as 
possible  of  events  down  to  the  18th  June,  1906,  when  the  MS.  left 
my  hands,  and  I  have  made  later  additions  and  corrections  whenever  I 
could  do  so  during  the  passage  of  the  book  through  the  press. 

If  cross-references  are  excluded,  the  index  to  Part  II.  contains  5354 
names. 

The  founder's  arms  on  the  title-page  are  reproduced  from  a  drawing 
made  by  the  Rev.  Edward  Earle  Dorling,  M.A.,  late  Vicar  of  Burcombe, 
Wilts.,  in  memory  of  his  friend  C.  W.  H. 

JOHN  B.   WAINEWRIGHT.    * 

June  5,  1907. 


CONTENTS. 


Pkeface       

Part  I. : — 

Wardens        

Fellows  

Head  Masters         

Second  Masters       

Tutors  and  Assistant  and  Temporary  Masters 

Houses  and  House  Masters       

Chaplains      ... 

Bursars  

Organists       

Index    

Part  II.  :— 

Scholars  and  Commoners  

Index

631-674 


Addenda  et  Corrigenda 


675-676 


PAKT   I. 

A  REGISTER  OF  WARDENS,  FELLOWS,  HEAD  MASTERS, 

SECOND  MASTERS,  TUTORS  AND  ASSISTANT 

AND   TEMPORARY  MASTERS, 

CHAPLAINS,  AND  ORGANISTS  OF  WINCHESTER  COLLEGE 

FROM   1836   TO   1905, 

WITH  BIOGRAPHICAL  NOTICES  OF  THE  SAME, 

TOGETHER   WITH 

A  LIST  OF  HOUSES  AND  THEIR  SUCCESSIVE  MASTERS, 
AND  ALPHABETICAL  INDEX. 


WARDENS. 


1832-61.  Rev.  Robert  Speckott  Barter,  b.  3  July,  1790,  3rd  and  y.  s.  of 

Rev.  Charles  Barter,  of  Cornworthy,  Devon,  and  Catherine, 

his  wife. 

Sch,  Win.  Coll,  1803 ;   Sch.  New  Coll.  Oxon  1807,  Fellow  1807-32,  B.C.L.  1815, 

Commoner  Tutor  Win.  Coll.  1812-14;    |^.©.,  d  about  1815,  p  about  181(), 

Tutor  New  Coll.  1815-30,  Bursar  1817,  Sub-warden  1820;   elected  Warden 

18  May,  1832,  R.  of  Greinton,  Somerset   1849-61.     ©   8    February,   1861. 

Inscription  in  Chapel.     Cf.  Adams,  "  Wykehamica,"  pp.  322-341 ;  Tuckwell, 

"The  Ancient  Ways,"  pp.  125-131. 

1861-1903.  Rev.  Godfrey  Bolles  Lee,  b.  19  March,  1817,  7th  s.  of  Robert 
Newton  Lee,  Esq.,  of  Coldrey,  Hants. 
Sch.  Win.  Coll.  1830;  Sch.  New  Coll.  Oxon  1834,  Fellow  1836-61,  B.A.  1839, 
M.A.  1844  [University  XI.  1838-9,  Capt.  1839],  College  Tutor  Win.  Coll. 
1839-60,  Bursar  New  Coll.  1860-1 ;  elected  Warden  1861 ;  ?^.®.,  d  1845, 
p  1846.  m  5  April,  1866,  Emma  Nunez,  y.  d.  of  Andrew  Fergushill  Craw- 
ford, Esq.,  M.D.,  of  Winchester.    IB  29  Jan.,  1903.    Inscription  in  Cloisters. 

Since  1904.  Sir  Kenneth  Augustus  Muir-Mackenzie,  K.C.B.,  K.C.,  b.  29 

June,  1846, 4th  s.  of  Sir  John  William  Pitt  Muir-Mackenzie, 

2nd  Bart.,  Delvine,  Perthshire,  and  Sophia  Matilda,  his 

wife,  5th  d.  of  James  Raymond  Johnstone,  Esq.,  of  Alma, 

Clackmannan. 

Charterhouse  School ;   Ball.  Coll.  Oxon  1864,  2  CI.  Mod.  1866,  2  CI.  B.A.  1868, 

]\I.A.  1873;   Barr.  Line.   Inn   1873,  Q.C.   1886,  Principal  Sec.   to   the  Lord 

Chancellor  since  1880,  and  a  Clerk  of  the  Crown  since  1885 ;   C.B.  1893 ; 

K.C.B.  1898  ;  co-opted  a  Fellow  of  Win.  Coll.  8  July,  1892,  vice  C.  W.  Chute, 

deceased ;  first  non- Wykehamist  elected  Warden  of  Win.  Coll.  since  it  took 

possession  of  its  buildings  28  March,  1393-4  ;  elected  14  Nov.,  1904,  under  the 

Statutes  made  9  July,  1904,  and  approved  by  the  King  in  Council  24  Oct., 

1904.     M  26  Feb.,  1874,  Amy,  d.  of  William  Graham,  Esq.,  late  M.P.  for 

Glasgow.   Address  20,  Queen  Aiine's  Gate,  S.W.   Club  Oxford  and  Cambridge. 


B  2 


Winchester  College. 


FELLOWS.

1838-93.  Rev.  Gilbert  Wall  Heatiicote,  b.   5  May,  1806,  e.  s.  of  Ven. 
Gilbert    Heathcote    (Schol.    1778),  Archdeacon   of    Win- 
chester, and  Sophia  Elizabeth,  his  1st  wife,  d.  of  Martin 
Wall,  P.R.S.,  M.D.  (Schol.  1760).

1832,  M.A.  1865,  Dean  of  Civil  Law  1834,  R.  of  Hursley  1829-36;  |^.©.,

deacon of  Gloucester.    1^  17  July,  1893.     Cf.  Leach,  "  Winchester  College," 
p.  513. 
1841-71.  Rev.  Gharles  Henry  Ridding,  bapt.  25   Sept.,  1796,  s.  of  John 
Ridding,  arm.  of  Winchester. 
Sch.  Win.  Coll.  1810;  Sch.  New  Coll.  1815,  Fellow  1817-24,  B.C.L.  1823;  %®., 
R.  RoUstone,  Wilts,  1824-71,  V.  Andover,  Hants  1835-71  ;  Ostiarius  Win.  Coll. 
1824-35  ;  Donor  of  Five  Courts,  and  understood  to  be  Donor  of  Racquet  Court. 
|H  29  July,  1824,  Charlotte,  d.  of  Rev.  Timothy  Stonhouse-Vigor,  afterwards 
Archdeacon  of  Gloucester.     ©    5    May,    1871,    when    his    Fellowship   was 
suppressed. 
1849-79.  Rev.  Henry  Blackstone  Williams,  b.  27  Dec,  1812,  only  s.  of 
Rev.  Canon  David  Williams,  D.C.L.  (Schol.  1799),  Gom- 
moner  Tutor  (1806-10),  Ostiarius  (1810-24),  and  Infor- 
mator  (1824-35)  of  Win.  Coll.  and  Warden  of  New  Coll. 
(1840-60),  and  his  wife,  d.  of  Rev.  William  Goddard.*

M.A.  1837,  Tutor  1837-45,  Dean  of  Divinity  1838,  of  Arts  1839,  Bursar  1840, 
Sub-warden  1841 ;  %}.®.,  d  1836,  p  1837,  C.  Bishop's  Canning,  Wilts.  1837-46, 
Select  Preacher  at  Oxford  1847-9,  Inc.  Southwick,  Hants  1847-50,  Preb.  of 
Salisbury    1870-9,    R.     Bradford    Peverel     1850-79.      M    21    June,    1845, 
Christiana,  e.  d.  of  Rev.  James  Baker  (Schol.  1800),  Chancellor  of  Durham  and 
R.  of  Nuneham  Courtenay,  Oxon.     ©  14  Dec,  1879. 

*  This  Rev.  William  Goddard  is  not  to  Ije  confused  with  the  Rev.  Dr.  William  Stanley  Goddard, 
Iiiformator,  1793-1809. 


6  Winchester  College. 

1851-80.  Rev.  Thomas  Frederick  Amelius  Parry  Hodges,  b.  5  May,  1801, 

s.  of  Walter  Hodges,  arm.  of  Easton  Gray,  Gloucestershire. 

Sch.  Win.  Coll.  1817  ;  Sch.  New  Coll.  Oxon  1821,  Fellow  1823-31,  B.C.L.  1829, 

D.C.L.  1838  ;  ^.®.,  d  1829,  p  1830,  V.  North  Clifton  with  Harbj'  1832-71, 

Lyme  Regis  1833-80.    IB  27  Oct.,  1880. 

1866-71.  Kev.  George  Moberly,  b.  10  Oct.,  1803,  7th  s.  of  Edward  Moberly, 
Esq.,  of  St.  Petersburg,  and  Sarah,  his  wife,  d.  of  John 
Cayley,  Esq.,  H.B.M.'s  Consnl-General  in  Russia. 
Sch.  Win.  Coll.  1816  ;   Sch.  Rail.  Coll.  Oxon  1822,  1  CI.  B.A.  1825,  Chancellor's 
English   Essay   1826,   M.A.    1828,   D.C.L.  1836.  Fellow   1826-34,   Tutor  and

Harrow  1820  ;  Ch.  Ch.  Oxon  1825,  Chancellor's  Latin  Verse  1827,  Student  Ch.  Ch.

College,   Glenalmond,   N.B.,  1845-53,  consecrated  Bishop  of  St.  Andrew's,

1884 ;    first  non-Wykehamist  to  be  elected  Fellow  for  centuries.    JH  (1)

Bungay;    (2)    28    Oct.,    1846,   'Katharine    Mary,    e.    d.   of    Rev.   William 

Brudenell  Barter  (bro.  of  Warden  Barter),  R.  of  Burghclere,  Hants,  'by  his 

first  wife.    IB  5  Dec,  1892.     For  a  list  of  his  works  and  a  full  record  of 

his  life,  see  D.N.B.  Ixiii.  1.    Cf.  also  Adams,  "Wykehamica,"  pas«i??!,  and 

Tuckwell,  "The  Ancient  Ways,"  pp.  135-45. 

[Note.*— The  Governing  Body  of  Winchester  College  was  established  by  a  Statute 
made  on  the  22nd  of  April,  1871,  by  the  Special  Commissioners  appointed  for  the  purposes 
of  the  Public  Schools  Act,  1868,  and  approved  on  the  28th  of  July,  1871,  by  her  late  Majesty 
in  Council.  It  consisted  of  the  Wardens  of  the  two  Colleges  of  St.  Mary  of  Winchester, 
virtute  officii,  and  of  six  others.  The  Governing  Body,  on  the  11th  of  November,  1871, 
co-opted  three  more  members,  two  of  whom,  viz.  the  Right  Hon.  Edward  Henry,  Earl  of 
Derby,  K.G.,  P.C,  D.C.L.,  LL.D.,  and  the  Right  Hon.  Sir  Stafford  Northcote,  P.C.,  C.B., 
D.C.L.,  M.P.,  resigned  on  the  21st  and  the  25th  of  January  respectively  in  the  j'ear  1873. 

By  Statute  V.  sec  1  of  the  Statutes  of  Winchester  College,  sealed  on  the  23rd  of  June, 
1873,  by  order  of  the  Governing  Body,  and  approved  on  the  20th  of  November,  1873,  by 
her  late  Majesty  in  Council  (the  said  Statute  V.  sec.  1  being  authorized  by  the  Public 
Schools  Act,  1871),  the  members  of  the  Governing  Body  of  Winchester  College,  other  than 
the  Warden  of  the  College,  became  Fellows  of  the  College,  together  with  the  existing 
Fellows  of  the  College ;  and  sec.  3  of  the  said  statute  provided  that  on  the  avoidance  of 
his  Fellowship  by  any  one  of  the  Fellows  existing  at  the  date  of  the  said  approval,  and 
not  being  a  member  of  the  Governing  Body  of  the  College,  such  Fellowship  should  not 
be  filled  up.] 

1873-1903.  Rev.  James  Edward  Sewell,  b.  25  Dec,  1810,  y.  s.  of  Thomas 
Sewell,  Esq.,  of  Newport,  I.W. 
Sch.  Win.  Coll.  1821 ;  Sch.  New  Coll.  Oxon  1827,  Fellow  1827-60,  B.A.  1832, 
M.A.  1835,  D.D.  1860,  Tutor  1835-60,  Dean  of  Arts  1835,  Bursar  1836,  Sub- 
warden  1839,  Dean  of  Divinity  1837,  Librarian  1842,  Warden  1860-1903; 
1^.®.,  A  1834,  p  1835;  an  original  member  of  the  Governing  Body  of  Win. 
Coll.,  virtute  officii,  1871,  Vice-Chancellor  of  Oxford  1874-78.  IB  29  Jan., 
1903.

acknowledge  all  the  items  for  which  thanks  are  due  to  him  without  covering  these  pages  with  footnotes ; 
60  I  thank  him  here  once  for  all.

1861,  1  CL,  2  L.  &  H.  B.A.  1863;  Fellow  Oriel  Coll.  Oxon  1864,  M.A.  1866, 
B.C.L.  1873,  D.C.L.  1898;  Senior  Proctor  187.5-6;  Lecturer  in  Jurisprudence 
Ch.  Ch.  1872-4,  Oriel  and  Lincoln  Colleges  1869-70,  Public  Examiner  in  Juris- 
prudence and  Modern  History  1869-70,  in  Jurisprudence  1876-7,  1878-80  ;  a 
Curator  of  the  Botanic  Garden  and  of  the  University  Chest,  a  Delegate  of  the 
University  Press,  etc.,  etc. ;  Provost  of  Oriel  Coll.  since  1905 ;  Barr.  Line. 
Inn  1872  ;  Inns  of  Court  Examiner  1881-4  :  Alderman  of  the  City  of  Oxford  ; 
Sheriff  of  Oxford  1894 ;  elected  Fellow  of  Win.  Coll.  (nice  Rev.  H.  D.  Harper 
resigned)  20  Jan.,  1890;  joint  editor  of  "Select  Titles  from  the  Digest  of 
Justinian"  ;  editor  of  W.  H.  Pater's  "Greek  Studies"  1895,  "Miscellaneous 
Studies"  1895,  and  "Gaston  de  Latour"  1896;  editor  of  "The  Laudian 
Statutes"  1888,  "The  University  and  College  Estate  Acts"  1898,  "Regislrum 
Orielense,"  2  vols.,  1893  and  1902;  author  of  "The  Purgatory  of  Dante  trans- 
lated into  English  Verse"  1892,  "The  Earthly  Paradise"  1899,  "History  of 
Oriel  College  "  in  Clark's  series,  1891.  Address  Oriel  College,  Oxon.  Clubs 
Athenaaum,  Oxford  and  Cambridge.

1841-6.  Herman  Ludolphus  Prior,  Esq.  (Senior  Part  Tutor),  b.  30  Sept.,

Sch.  Trin,  Coll.  Oxon  1836-42,  2  Cl.B.A.  1841,  M.A.  1847  ;  Barr.  Line.  Inn  1850, 

ceased  to  practise  1885  ;  author  of  "A  Manual  of  Short  Conveyancing"  1857, 

"A  Guide  to  the  English  Lakes"  1865  and  1882,  and  of  the  following  novels, 

"The  Heirs  of  Chieveley"  1858,  "Six  Months  Hence"  1870,  "Behind  the 

'      Veil"    1871,    "Expiated"    1872,    "Overmatched"    1876;    also   of    a    poem, 

"Miserrima"  1890;  editor  of  Juvenal  in  Bell's  Grammar  School  Series  1862, 

and  of  Selections  from  Southey  1871.    Eesided  at  Ivy  Cottage,  Snaresbrook, 

Essex.    ©  1903.

Winchester.

26  Winchester  College. 


HOUSES   AND   HOUSE  MASTERS.'- 

Chernocke  House  (J). 
Rev.  H.  J.  WiCKHAM,  Short  Half,  1859,  to  Cloister  Time,  1888,  iaclusive. 
Rev.  W.  p.  Smith,  Short  Half,  1888,  to  Common  Time,  1894,  inclusive. 
John  Sampson  Fukley,  Esq.,  since  Cloister  Time,  1894. 

Kingsgate  St.  (B). 
Rev.  H.  E.  Moberly,  Long  Half,  1860,  to  Cloister  Time,  1880,  inclusive. 
Aelingham  James  Toye,  Esq.,  Short  Half,  1880,  to  Common   Time,  1899, 

inclusive. 
James  Alfred  Fort,  Esq.,  since  Cloister  Time,  1899. 

Southgate  Hill  (C). 
Rev.  J.  H.  T.  du  Boulay,  opened  the  3rd  house  for  Commoners  on  11  Feb., 
1862,  at  91,  Cheesehill  St.,  but  removed  it  to  Southgate  Hill, 
18  June,  1863.  He  resigned  at  the  end  of  Cloister  Time, 
1893,  since  which  dale  A.  K.  Cook,  Esq.,  has  been  House 
Master. 

Culver  House  (D). 
The  4.th  house  was  opened  by  Rev.  W.  A.  Fearon  in  Long  Half,  1868,  at  22, 
Kingsgate  St.,  and  was  removed  to  Culver  House  in  June, 
1867.  He  resigned  at  the  end  of  Common  Time,  1882,  and 
was  succeeded  by  T.  Kensington,  Esq.,  who  resigned  at  the 
end  of  Cloister  Time,  1904,  and  was  succeeded  by  Rev. 
F.  P.  David. 

Southgate  Road,  now  Southgate  Corner  {E). 
The  5th  house  was  opened  by  F.  Morshead,  Esq.,  in  Cheesehill  St.,  but  was 
soon  removed  to  Soutligate  Road.  He  resigned  at  the  end 
of  Cloister  Time,  1905,  and  was  succeeded  by  N.  C.  Smith, 
Esq.,  who  has  changed  the  name  of  the  house  to  Southgate 
Corner. 

Southgate  House  (F). 
Rev,  C.  H.  Hawkins  opened  this  house  at  the  beginning  of  Common  Time,  1869, 
and  resigned  at  the  end  of  Cloister  Time,  1900,  when  he 
was  succeeded  by  E.  H.  Buckland,  Esq.,  who  died  10  Feb., 
1906,  and  was  succeeded  by  G.  H.  Blore,  Esq. 

Culver  Lea  {O). 
Rev.  E.  W.  Sergeant,  Short  Half,  1869,  to  Short  Half,  1882,  inclusive. 
C.  B.  Phillips,  Esq.,  Common  Time,  1883,  to  Short  Half,  1895,  inclusive. 
Rev.  G.  M.  A.  Hewitt,  since  Common  Time,  1896. 

Culvefs  Close  (H). 
Rev.  J.  T.  Bramston,  since  Short  Half,  1869. 

Sunnyside  (I). 
E.  J.  Turner,  Esq.,  Short  Half,  1869,  to  Cloister  Time,  1903,  inclusive. 
Rev.  A.  G.  Bather,  s'mce  Short  Half,  1903. 

Kingsgate  House  {K). 
R.  D,  Beloe,  Esq.,  since  22  Sept.,  1905. 

*  For  biographies  of  the  House  Masters,  see  the  preceding  list. 


Winchester  College,  27 


CHAPLAINS. 

1808-52.  Rev.  Thomas  Westcombe,  s.  of  Rev.  Nicholas  Westoorabe,  (^aplain 

of  Winchester  College  and  of  the  Hants  County  Hospital, 

Minor  Canon  of  Winchester  Cathedral,  and  R.  of  Barton 

Stacey,  Hants,  who  was  murdered  by  a  soldier  of  the  102nd 

Regt.,  13  Aug.,  1813. 

Triu.  Coll.  Oxon  1803,  B.A.  1807,  M.A.  1810,  Chapl.  Hants  County  Hosp.  1814, 

Minor  Canon  of  Winchester  Cathedral,  V.  of  Preston  Candover,  Hants  1826-52, 

and  of  Letcombe  Regis,  Berks  182G-52.    IE.    13  at  Preston  Candover  25  July, 

1852,  aged  67. 

1813-39.  Rev.  Thomas  Watkins,  s.  of  Thomas  Watkins,  Esq.,  of  Hereford. 

Ch.  Ch.  Oxon  1793,  B.A.  1797,  M.A.  1801 ;  V.-choral  Hereford  Cathedral  1797,  V. 
Minty,  Wilts.  1810.    M   before  1841. 

1828-60.  Rev.  Francis  Swanton,  b.  17  Dec,  1791,  s.  of  Rev.  Francis  Swauton, 

of  Worthy. 

Sch.  Win.  Coll,  1805;  Wadh.  Coll.  Oxon   1810,  Exhibnr.   1811-14,  B.C.L.  1817, 

"Sub-preceptor"   Win.   Coll,   1815-29,    V.    St.   John's,    Winton   1827-71,   V. 

Piddletrenthide,  Dorset  1827-45,  V.  Barton  Stacev,  Hants  1845-71.    M  2  Nov., 

1871, 

1839-59,  Rev.  William  Henry  Gunner.     See  above,  p.  13. 

1852-62.  Rev.  Octavius  Arthur  Hodosox,  y.  s.  of  Rev,  Charles  Henry 
Hodgson,  of  Salisbury, 
Chorister  Magd.  Coll.  Oxon  1830-6,  Clerk  1836-41,  B.A.  1840,  M.A.  1846  ;  |§.(©., 
d  1841,  p  1842,  C.  Dinton,  Wilts.  1841-3,  Minor  Canon  Win.  Cath.  1845-62, 
C.  St.  Peter's,  Cheesehill,  Winton  1851-2,  V.  Alton,  Hants  1862-74,  R.  East 
Stoke,  Dorset  1874-95.  fK-  IB  at  Stoke  Lodge,  Sandown,  Isle  of  Wight, 
21  Oct.,  1903. 

1858-95.  Rev,  James  Baker.     See  Part  II.,  p.  35, 
1860-3.  Rev.  Hejjry  Edward  Moberlt.     See  Part  II.,  p.  37. 
1862-1900.  Rev.  Charles  Halford  Hawkins.     See  above,  pp.  15,  26. 
1863-77.  Rev.  George  Beckwith,  e.  s.  of  Rev.  Edward  George  Ambrose  Beck-

28  Winchester  College. 


BUKSAKS.* 

1836.  Eevv.  Harry  Lee  aud  Henry  Sissmore. 

1837.  Revv.  H.  Lee  and  Andrew  Quicke. 

1838.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  Gilbert  Wall  Heathcote. 

1839.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  H.  Sissmore. 

1840.  Revv.  H.  Lee  and  A.  Quicke. 

1841.  Revv.  George  Gumming  Rashleigh  and  A.  Quicke. 

1842.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  Charles  Henry  Ridding. 

1843.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  G.  0.  Rashleigh. 

1844.  Revv.  H.  Sissmore  and  A.  Quicke. 

1845.  Revv.  G.  C.  Rashleigh  and  A.  Quicke. 

1846.  Revv.  H.  Lee  and  A.  Quicke. 

1847.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  C.  H.  Ridding. 

1848.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  G.  W.  Heathcote. 

1850.  Revv.  H.  Lee  and  A.  Quicke. 

1851.  Revv.  G.  C.  Rashleigh  and  A.  Quicke. 
1862.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  C.  H.  Ridding. 

1853.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  G.  W.  Heathcote. 

1854.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  T.  F.  A.  P.  Hodges. 

[From  Christmas,  1854,  J.  D.  Walford,  Esq.  (above,  p.  13),  was  Assistant  Bursar, 
with  a  stipend  of  £200  per  annum  down  to  his  death.] 

1855.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  G.  C.  Rashleigh. 

1856.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  Henry  Blackstone  Williams. 

1857.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  C.  II.  Ridding. 

1858.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  G.  W.  Heathcote. 

1859.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  T.  F.  A.  P.  Hodges. 
[Bursars  received  £120  per  annum  from  this  year.] 

1860.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  H.  Lee. 

1861.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  G.  C.  Rashleigh. 

1862.  Revv.  A.  Quicke  and  H.  B.  Williams. 

[After  1862  the  names  of  Bursars  arc  not  recorded  till  1874.  The  Bursars'  book  is 
mainly  in  Mr.  Heathcote's  handwriting,  and  it  is  probable  that  he  acted  alone, 
with  the  assistance  of  Mr.  Walford,  though  the  £120  is  entered  every  year 
opposite  the  word  "  Bursars."] 

*  I  am  indebted  to  the  kinduess  of  the  present  Bursar  for  this  list. — J.  B.  W. 


"Winchester  College.  29 

1874  to  Michaelmas,  1877.  Rev.  G.  W.  Heathcote,  who  retired  at  the  latter 
date  on  £150  a  year  and  the  title  of  Sub-warden. 

Since  Michaelmas,  1877.  Thomas  Frederick  Kirby,  Esq.,  b.  3  Sept.,  1836, 

e.  s.  of  Commander  Thomas  Kirby,  R.N.,  of  Inhurst,  Hants, 

and  Louisa  Elizabeth,  his  wife,  d.  of  Robert  Becher,  Esq., 

of  Chancellor  House,  Tunbridge  Wells. 

Oppidan  at  Eton  1848-55  ;  Pensioner  Trin.  Coll.  Camb.  1855, 1  CI.  B.A.  1859,  M.A. 

1862,  Fellow  and  Assist.  Tutor  Trin.  Coll.  1861-4;    Barr.  Line.  Inn   1866; 

F.S.A. ;  J.P.  Hants  ;  author  of  "  Winchester  Scholars,"  "  Annals  of  Winchester 

College,"  and  numerous  papers  in  "  Archseologia,"  and  editor  of  Wykeham's 

Episcopal  Register  for  the  Hants  Record  Soc.    ilH  3  Oct.,  1865,  Helen,  only 

surv.  d.  of  Walter  John  Hunter,  Esq.,  late  of  B.C.S.     Address  7,  College  St., 

Winchester. 


30  Winchester  College.

in  Cloisters.

PART   II. 

WINCHESTER    COLLEGE, 
1836-1905. 

A  REGISTER  OF  THE   SCHOLARS  AND  COMMONERS 

ADMITTED  TO  THE  SCHOOL 

BETWEEN  THE  BEGINNING   OF  183G   AND 

THE   END   OF   1005. 


REV.  GEORGE  MOBERLY,  M.A.  (afterwards  D.C.L.)  '^ 
Elected  Ikformatob,  1G  Jan.,  1836. 


ENTRANCES. 
LONG  HALF  (January  to  July),  1836. 

[Names  to  which  the  mark  (f)  is  attached  are  those  of  Scholars.  For  the  House  Letters, 
see  Part  L  above,  at  p.  26.  Names  to  which  no  letter  or  mark  is  attached  are 
those  of  Commoners  who  were  in  "Old  Commoners."  Where  the  word  "to"  is 
prefiKcd  to  a  House  Letter,  the  person  in  each  case  to  whose  name  the  sign,  e.g.  (to  A), 
is  attached  entered  Old  Commoners,  hut  subsequently  changed  to  the  House  denoted 
by  the  House  Letter.] 

Baker,  James  (f),  b.  22  April,  1825,  e.  s.  of  Rev.  James  Baker  (f  1800),  E.  of 

Nuneham  Courtney,  Oxon ;  afterwards  Chancellor  of  Durham 

Cathedral    (bro.    of    Frederick,    Henry,    Granville,    and 

Montagu  Bernard,  below,  pp.  74,  106,  124,  136). 

Univ.  Coll.  Oxon  1843,  3  CI.  B.A.  1847,  M.A.  1850;  |^.©.,  rf  1851,  p  1853  Oxf., 

C.   Gt.   Milton,    Oxon    1852-3,    Croft,   Yorks.  1854-8,  Pitt.   Hants   1859  ;  \i. 

St.   Swithun's,    Winchester    1859-63;    Chapl.    Win.    Coll.    1858-95,     Hants 

County  Hospital  1885-95.    B  19  June,  1897. 

Bennett,  Henry  Edward,  b.  10  Sept.,  1822,  at  Haselgrove,  e.  s.  of  Rev.  Henry 

Bennett,  of  Sparkford,  Somerset,  and  Emily,  his  wife,  d.  of 

Edward  Moberly,  Esq.,  of  Petersburg,  and  sister  of  Rev. 

George  Moberly  (bro.  of  William  Henry,  Edward  James, 

George,  James  Arthur,  Francis  Cay  ley,  and  Charles  "William, 

below,  pp.  53,  58,  84,  112,  145,  157). 

St.  John's  Coll.  Camb.,  B.A.  1844  ;  Barr.  Inner  T.  1848  ;  resident  in  Upper  Canada 

for  some  years  ;    J.P.  Somerset ;   Capt.   1st  Somerset  Militia  1872-81.    f^ 

26  Nov.,  1857,  Louisa  Birchall,  d.  and  co-heiress  of  Hon.  Sir  James  Buchanan 

Macaulay,  C.B.,  C.J.  of  Toronto,  and  Rachel  Cruikshank,  his  wife,  d.  of  John 

Gamble  ;  resided  at  Sparkford  Hall.    IB   at  Colwyn  Bay,  22  May,  1897. 

Bridge,  John  Moore,  b.  25  Dec,  1821,  only  s.  of  Robert  Bridge,  Esq.,  Wyke, 

Weymouth. 

Magdalen  Hall,  Oxon  1842,  B.A.  1845,  M.A.  1849;  |^.©.,  eZ  1850,  p  1851,  C.  St. 

John,  Keswick  1850-3,  Hamble  1854-6.    f^  1849,  Emma,  d.  Thomas  Bridge, 

Esq.,    Monte  Video    House,  Weymouth.     ©   at  Lorton  House,   Broadway, 

Dorchester,  7  March,  1901. 

Carmichael,  William  Hugh  Hedges,  b.  at  Killarney,  1822, 2nd  s.  of  Lieut.-Col. 

John  Carmichael,  6th  D.  G.,  of  Duncroft  House,  Staines, 

and  18,  Rue  Basse,  St.  Pierre,  Chaillot,  Paris. 

R.M.C.   Sandhurst,  1837,  passed  out  iirst;  Presentation  Sword  1840,  Ens.  1840 

79th  Regt.,  Lieut.  1844,  Adjut.  1845,  Capt.  1847,  invalided  1847.  13  at  Hastings, 

7  April,  1848  ;  buried  at  Staines. 

D  2 

/ 


36  Winchester  College.  1836 

Feith,  James  (f),  b.  18  April,  1821,  2nd  s.  of  Eev.  Edward  Cokayne  Frith, 
Hambledon,  Hants  (bro.  ofWilliani  Armetriding,  below,  p.  65). 
Westminster  School  1833-35,  King's  Scholar  183.5  ;  Ch.  Ch,  Oxon  1840,  4  Math. 
B.A.  1844,  M.A.  1848;  ^.(B-,  d  1845,  p  1846  Worcs.,  C.  Hartley,  Worcs. 
1845-8,  Bishop's  Itchingtou,  Warws.  1848-50,  South  Moreton,  Berks  1852-65, 
Bisley,  Glouc.  1868-74 ;  V.  St.  Saviour,  Coalpit  Heath,  Bristol  1874-81 ; 
R.  Aiwington,  Devon  1881-1901.    ©  24  Sept.,  1901. 

Gray,  James  Chaeles  (f),  b.  1  Jan.,  1826,  at  Southampton,  s.  of  Rev.  James 
Gray,  V.  of  Dibden,  Hants. 
Left  17  April,  1837.     Secretary  to  Southampton  Savings  Bank,  West  Marlands, 
Southampton ;  residing  in  1880  at  Hanover  House,  Millbrook  Road,  Freemantle, 
Southampton,    S, 

IIaksaed,  Eichard  James,  b.  18  Dec,  1821,  5th  s.  of  Luke  Graves  Hansard,

AuKOLD,  Thomas,  b.  30  Nov.,  1823,  at  Laleliam  (bro.  of  (be  above). 

To  liuyby  1837 ;  Sch.  Univ.  Coll.  Oxou  1842,  1  CI.  B.A.  1845,  M.A.  1865 ;  Stud. 
Line.  Inn  1846  ;  Clerk  in  Colonial  Office  1847  ;  to  New  Zealand  1847  ;  started  a 
school  at  Fort  Hill,  near  Nelson,  1849  ;  Inspector  of  Schools  in  Tasmania 
1850-6 ;  received  into  Catholic  Church  1856 ;  Professor  of  English  Literature 
at  Cath.  Univ.  Dublin,  1856-62  ;  First  Classical  Master  in  the  Oratory  School, 
Edgbaston  1862  ;  left  the  Catholic  Church  in  1865,  but  was  subsequently 
received  back  again  ;  Fellow  of  Royal  University  and  Prof,  of  English  in  Univ. 
Coll.  Dublin  1882-1900;  author  of  "A  Manual  of  English  Literature"  1862, 
"Chaucer  to  Wordsworth  "  1868,  "Passages  in  a  Wandering  Life"  1900,  "i^nd 
other  works  ;  joint-author  with  W.  E.  Addis  of  "  A  Catholic  Dictionary  "  1883. 
ilSl  (1)  13  June,  1850,  Julia,  d.  of  William  Sorrell,  of  Hobart;  (2)  in  1890, 
Josephine,  d.  of  James  Benison,  of  Slieve  Russell,  co.  Cavan.  13  at  Dublin, 
12  Nov.,  1900.    See  D.N.B.  Supp.  i.  76.

CuNLiFFE,  Foster  (f),  b.  6  April,  1825,  in  Madras,  2nd  s.  of  Brooke  Cuulift'c,

3rd  Bombay  Light  Cavalry  1842,  Capt.  1850,  Brevet-Major  1858,  Staff  Corps  1802  ; 
served  in  Scindc  campaign  1843  ;  A.D.C.  to  Gen.  Rattle  at  battle  of  Hyderabad 
(medal) ;  interpreter  in  three  native  languages,  held  various  staff  appointments 
in  his  own  regiment  and  elsewhere  ;  Assist.  Political  Agent  in  Kaltywar  1855, 
Acting    Political    Agent  in   Rewa    Kanta   1850-04 ;    served   through    Indian 
Mutiny,  including  battle  of  Oodeypoor  (medal,  Brevet-Major,  twice  mentioned 
in  despatches,  thanked  by  the  Government  of  Bombay,  the  Government  of 
India,  and  H.M.  the  Queen),  1858  ;   Lieut.-Col.  (retired)  1864.    j0  at  Shaken-

Waud,  Habey  Leigh  Douglas,  b.  18  Feb.,  1825,  4th  s.  of  Rev.  Jolin  Giflfard 
Ward,  afterwards  Dean  of  Lincoln. 
Univ.  Coll.  Oxon  1844,  B.A.  1847 ;  Halle  Univ.  Ph.D.,  A.L.M.  ;  Assist.  MSS. 
Dept.  British  Museum  1849-93  ;  editor  "Catalogue  of  Romances  in  the  British 
Museum  MSS.,"  vol.  i.  1883,  vol.  ii.  1893 ;  his  knowledge  of  the  Arthurian  and 
Charlemagne  cycles  was  probably  unrivalled  ;  he  was  a  friend  of  Coventry 
Patmore,  T.  W."  Robertson,  and  Rev.  W.  H.  Brooktield  ;  also  of  D.  G.  Rossetti.

dentally shot  himself  when  endeavouring  ^to  reach  the  pistol." — O'ent.  Mag,

Bright,  Robert  Onesipiiorus,  b.  7  July,  1823,  2nd  s.  of  Robert  Bright,  Esq.,

At  Eugby  1837-8;  19th  Regt.,  Ensign  1843,  Lieut.  1847,  Capt.  1852,  IMajor  1855, 

Lieut.-Col.  185G,  Col.  18G2,  Major-Gen.  1868;  Crimean  War  1854-5,  including 

Alma  and  Inkerman,  the  siege  and  fall  of  Sebastopol,  and  the  storming  of  the 

Redan  (mentd.  in  despatches,  medal  with  three  clasps.  Brevet  Lieut.-Col.,  Knt. 

of  the  Legion  of  Honour,  5th  Class  INIedjidio,  and  Turkish  medal)  ;  commanded 

as  Brigadier-Gen.  1st  Hazara  Field  Force  1868,  including  the  Black  Mountain 

Expedition  (mentd.  in  despatches,  thanked  by  Indian  Govt.,  C.B.,  medal  with 

clasp)  ;  Afghan  War  1879-80,  in  command  of  Khyber  Line  Field  Force  (mentd. 

in  despatches,  thanked  by  both  Houses  of  Parliament  5  May,  1881,  K.C.B. 

and   medal).     f&,   1856,  Catherine,  4th   d.    of   Sir  William   Allies,    1st  Bart.

BucKLAND,  Francis  Trevelyan  (f),  b.  17  Dec,  1826,  at  Christ  Church,  Oxon, 
s.  of  Williani  Buckland  (f  1798),  afterwards  Dean  of  West- 
minster, and  Mary,  his  wife,  d.  of  Benjamin  Moiland,  Esq., 
of  Sheepstead  House,  near  Abingdon,  Berks  (bro.  of  Edward 
Copleston,  below,  p.  75). 
Ch.  Ch.  Oxon,  B.A.  1848 ;  Stud.  St.  George's  Hosp.  1848-51,  House  Surgeon  1852-3, 
Assist.  Surgeon  2nd  Life  Guards  1854;    on  the  Staff  of  the  Field  1856-65, 
founder  of  Land  and  WaterlSGG,  Inspector  of  Salmon  Fisheries  1867  ;  frequent 
writer  in  the  Field  and  Land  and  Water,  author  of  annual  reports  on  salmon 
fisheries  and  other  reports  on  fisheries,  etc.    The  books  by  which  he  is  best 
known  are  his  "  Cariosities  of  Natural  History,"  4  vols.  1857-72  ;  the  "  Logbook 
of  a  Fisherman  and  Zoologist"  1875  ;  an  edition  of  White's  "Natural  History 
of  Selborne,"  with  original  notes ;  and  the  "  Natural  History  of  British  Fishes." 
(For  further  particulars,  see  D.N.B.  vii.  204.)    ©  19  Dec.,  1880.

L'EsTRANGE,  George  Henry,  b.  29  Julj',  1825,  e.  s.  of  George  Burdett 
L'Estrange,  Esq.,  Lisnamandra,  Crossdoney,  Ireland  (Gentle-

1858,  Knt.  1860),  and his  wife,  d.  of  Herbert  Rawson 

Stepney,  Esq. 
Had  one  eye  severely  inj  ured  by  a  cricket  ball ;  removed  to  Eton  1841 ;  Trin.  Coll. 
Dublin  1842  ;  Land  Agent ;  Agent  for  the  Marquis  of  Waterford's  Leitrim  estates 
1863-70,  and  for  many  other  extensive  properties  ;  J.P.  Cavan.  f^  1852,  Augusta

Lipscomb,  William  (f),  b.  9  Aug.,  1825,  at  Kensington,  s.  of  William  Lips- 
comb, Esq.,  of  the  War  Office. 
Left  10  July,  1843 ;  Ranger  of  Delamarc  Forest ;  pupil  to  Mr.  Bradley,  land  agent, 
Richmond,  Yorks. ;  joined  engineering  and  surveying  staff  Caledonian  Railway 
at  Lanark ;  Agent  for  Earl  of  Scarborough's  Yorkshire  estates  1849 ;  subse- 
quently Agent  to  Col.  Henry  Savilc,  Sir.  Augustus  W.  Lumley-Savile,  and  the 
1st  and  2nd  Barons  Savile ;  President  West  Riding  Agricultural  Chamber  ; 
Member  of  Council  Central .  Chamber  of  Agriculture ;  appointed  to  several 
Parliamentary  Committees ;  author  of  Synopsis  of  Agricultural  Holdings 
Bill ;  Member  of  Council  Yorkshire  Coll. ;  J.P.  West  Riding;  Member  High- 
way Committee,  f^  (1)  26  April,  1855,  Laura  Helen,  e.  d.  of  the  late  William 
Stansfeld,  Esq.,  of  the  Manor  House,  Flockton,  Yorks. ;  (2)  23  April,  1878, 
Emily  Blanche,  d.  of  Rev.  Robert  Gamson.  ©  16  Sept.,  1904,  at  his  shooting- 
box,  Walshaw  Moor,  Hebden  Bridge.

Malleson,  George  Bruce,  b.  1825,  2nd  s.  of  John  Malleson,  Esq.,  Wimbledon 
(bro.  of  the  next,  and  of  Edward,  below,  p.  73). 
Bengal  Staff  Corps  1842,  Lieut.  1847,  Capt.  1857,  Major  1862,  Lieut.-Col.  1868,  Col. 
1873,  retired  1877  ;  in  Indian  Military  Defence  Dept.  1856-63,  Sanitary  Com- 
missioner to  Indian  Govt.  1865-9,  Controller-Gen.  Military  Finances  18G8, 
Guardian  Maharajah  of  Mysore  1869-72,  C.S.I.  1872;  received  into  the  Catholic 
Church  1891  ;  author  of  "The  IMutiny  of  the  Bengal  Army,"  better  known  as 
the  "  Red  Pamphlet"  1857,  "History  of  the  French  in  India"  1868  and  1893, 
"Recreations  of  an  Indian  Official"  1872,  "Studies  from  Genoese  History" 

1875,  "Historical  Sketch  of  Native  States"   1875,   "Essays  and  Lectures" 

1876,  "Final  French  Struggles  in  India"  1878  and  1884,  "History  of  the 
Indian  Mutiny  1857-8"  1878-80  and  1890,  "History  of  Afghanistan"  18/9; 
editor  of  Eyre's  "Kabul  Insurrection"  1879;  author  of  "Herat"  1880, 
"Founders  of  the  Indian  Empire"  1882,  "Decisive  Battles  of  India"  1883 
and  1885,  "  Captain  Musafir's  Rambles"  1883,  "The  Battlefields  of  Germany" 
1884,  "London"  1884,  " Russo- Afghan  Question"  1885,  "Ambushes  and 
Surprises"  1885,  "Prince  Eugene"  1888,  " Prince  Mettemich "  1888  and  1895, 
"Akbar"  1890,  "Refounding  of  German  Empire"  1892,  "Life  of  Marquis 
"Wellesley"  1895,  "Lakes  and  Rivers  of  Austria"  1897.  ^  1856,  Marion 
Charlotte,  only  d.  of  George  Wynyard  Baltye,  Esq.,  B.C.S.  M  at  27,  "West 
Cromwell  Road,  London,  1  March,  1898.     Cf.  D.N.B.  Supp.  iii.  135.

J3  29  Maj',  1847,  unmarried,  accidentally  shot  at  Montevideo,  South  America,  the 

shot  passing  through  the  intended  victim  and  afterwards  entering  the  body  of 

Mr.  Dickson,  who  was  walking  a  few  j^ards  in  front  of  him.

H08KINS,  Anthony  IIiley,  b.  1  Sept.,  1828,  s.  of  Eev.  Henry  Hoskins, 
of  North  Perr.tt  Manor,  Crewkerne,  Somerset,  and  Mary, 
his  wife,  d.  of  Eev.  William  Phelips,  of  Montacute  House, 
Somerset  (bro.  of  Arthur  lleginald  and  Edmond  John, 
below,  pp.  89,  107). 
Tcuth  on  the  Roll  "ad  Winton"  1842,  but  renounced  and  entered  R.N.  as  a  mid- 
shipman the  same  year  ;  present  at  attack  on  Tamatare  by  the  Comvaij  18  June, 
1845 ;  commanded  cutter  of  the  President  in  attack  on  Arab  stockades  at 
Aujoxa,  Mozambique  Channel,  1847  ;  Sub. -Lieut.  1848,  Lieut.  1849 ;  Lieut,  of 
the  Castor  in  Kaffir  War  1851-2 ;  Naval  A.D.C.  to  Sir  Harry  Smith,  present 
at  actions  at  Amatola  and  Watcrcloof  (several  times  mentioned  in  despatches, 
medal) ;  in  command  of  the  gunboat  Beaver  1856  ;  Lieut.-Commandcr  of  the 
Slaney  during  Chinese  War  1857-8,  present  at  the  capture  of  Canton,  Dec, 
1857,  and  Taku  forts  INIay,  1858  (despatches,  medal  with  two  clasps)  ; 
Commander  under  date  26  Feb.,  1858 ;  Capt.  12  Dec,  1873 ;  commanded  the 
Eclipse  on  N.  American  station  1869-72,  and  the  Sultan  in  the  Channel  Fleet 
1873-4;  Commodore  on  the  Australian  station  1875-8;  Naval  A.D.C.  to  the 
Queen  1877-9  ;  C.B.  1877 ;  Rear-Admiral  15  June,  1879 ;  Naval  Lord  of  the 
Admiralty  1880-2  ;  Egyptian  War  1882  (2nd  class  Medjidie,  K.C.B.,  medal, 
Khedive's  star,  and  thanks  of  Parliament)  ;  Superintendent  of  Naval  Reserves 
1882-5 ;  Vice- Admiral  1885 ;  Naval  Lord  of  the  Admiralty  1885-9  ;  Grand 
Cordon  Medjidie  1889;  Commander-in-Chief  in  the  Mediterranean  1889-91; 
Admiral  1891 ;  First  Naval  Lord  1891-3;  thanked  by  the  French  Govt.,  and 
received  a  present  of  Sevres  china  for  assistance  given  to  a  French  gunboat 
at  Jaffa  1891;  Commissioner  of  Patriotic  Fund,  Aug.,  1893;  iF.R.G.S. ;  on 
the  Council  of  the  Royal  Service  Institution,  Hakluyt  Societj'-,  etc.,  etc.  ; 
G.C.B.  and  good  service  pension  on  retiring  Nov.,  1893.  fH  27  Oct.,  1865, 
Dorothea  Anne  Eliza,  2nd  d.  of  Rev.  Sir  George  Stamp  Robinson,  7th  Bart., 
who  survived  him  but  a  few  months.  J3  at  Pleystowe,  Capel,  near  Dorking, 
21  June,  1901.     Cf.  N.  and  Q.,  10th  S.,  iii.  26.

X)r.  Ullathornc,  Bp.  of  Birmingham  18G1 ;  Private  Secretary  and  Literary

Nugent,  Charles  Butler  Peter  Nugent  Hodges  (f),  b.  25  Sept.,  1825,  at 
Walcot,  Bath,  s.  of  0.  Nugent,  Esq. 
2ud  Lieut.  R.E.  1845,  Lieut.  1846,  Capt.  1854,  Brev.-Major  1855,  Brev.-Lieut.-Co 
1866,  Brcv.-Col.  1873,  Col.  1878,  retired  1883 ;  served  in  the  Baltic  during  the 
Russian  War  1854-5 ;  in  1854  as  Senior  Engineer  Officer  attached  to  the 
Commander-in-Chief,  Admiral  Sir  Charles  Napier  ;  present  at  capture  of  Aland 
Islands  and  fall  of  Bomarsund  ;  in  1855  attaclied  to  the  Commander-in-Chief, 
Admiral  Sir  R.  Dundas,  and  present  at  the  bombardment  of  Sweaborg  (Baltic 
medal  and  Brevet  of  Major)  ;  Assistant  Director  of  Works  and  Fortifications  at 
War  Office  1871-5,  Deputy-Director  1876-81,  C.B.  1873;  in  command  of  R.E. 
Egyptian  Expedition  1882  (mentioned  in  despatches,  medal,  bronze  star,  2nd 
Class  Medjidie) ;  K.C.B.  1882  ;  retired  on  full  pay  Sept.,  1884.  fE  1868,  Emma,

Gabdikek,  Samuel  Kawson,  b.  4  Marcb,  1829,  at  llopley,  near  Alrcsfonl,  e.  s. 
of  Rawson  Boddam  Gardiner,  Esq.,  of  Ropley  (afterwards 
of  7,  Eoclsstone  Place,  Southampton),  and  Margaret,  his 
wife,  2i)d  d.  of  William  Baring-Gould,  Esq.,  of  Lew  Trcn- 
chard,  Devoushiie  (bio.  of  Charles  Baring,  below,  p.  109). 
Ch.  Ch.  Oxon  1847,  Stud.  1850-5,  1  CI.  B.A.  1851 ;  Professor  of  History  at  King's 
Coll.  London  1871-85 ;  Lecturer  for  the  London  Society  for  the  Extension  of 
University  Teaching  1880-94  ;  a  Member  of  the  Irvingite  Church  for  more  than 
twenty  years  from  1865  ;  Hon.  Student  Ch.  Ch.  Oxon  1878  ;  Civil  List  Pension 
of  £150  p.a.  1882 ;  research  Fellow  of  All  Souls  Coll.  Oxon  1884-92 ;  Fellow 
of  Merton  Coll.  Oxon  1892-1902;  Examiner  in  History  at  London  University 
1880-1901;  Examiner  Hist.  Final  School,  Oxford  1886-9;  M.A.  Oxon  1884; 
Hon.  Ph.D.  Gottingen,  Hon.  LL.D.  Edinburgh ;  offered  but  declined  Eegius 
Professorship  of  Modern  Historj'^,  Oxon  1894 ;  Hon.  D.C.L.  Oxon  1894 ; 
1st  Ford  Lecturer  at  Oxford  1896  (when  his  Lectures  "Cromwell's  Place 
in  History"  were  published  in  1897,  they  had  to  be  recovered  from  the 
notes  of  his  auditors,  he  having  lectured  wholly  from  memory) ;  author  of 
"  History  of  England  1603-42,"  first  published  in  5  sets  of  two  vols,  each  with 
separate  titles,  1863-81,  but  re-issued  as  a  whole  1884,  "  History  of  Great  Civil 
War  1862-49,"  3  vols.  1886-91,  "History  of  Commonwealth  and  Protectorate," 
to  be  completed  in  5  vols.,  of  which  three  onlv  were  published  1894-1901,  "  The 
Thirty  Years'  War  "  1874,  "  The  First  Two  Stuarts  "  1876,  "  Outline  of  English 
History,"  3  pts.  1881-3,  "  Students'  History  of  England,"  3  pts.  1891,  "  School 
Atlas  of  English  Historj^"  "What  Gunpowder  Plot  AVas"  1897,  "Cromwell" 
1899  ;  contributor  to  Mullinger's  "Introduction  to  English  History"  1881,  and 
throughout  to  the  Diet.  Nat.  Biog. ;  edited  a  long  series  of  volumes  for  the 
Camden  Society,  of  which  he  was  director ;  editor  of  "  Constitutional  Documents 
of  the  Puritan  Revolution"  for  Clarendon  Press  1889,  and  "Letters  and  Papers 
illustrating  the  Relations  between  Charles  II.  and  Scotland  in  1650"  for 
Scottish  Hist.  Soc.  1894,  and  "Letters  and  Papers  relating  to  the  First  Dutch 
War"  for  Navy  Record  Society  1899;  editor  of  English  Historical  Review 
from  1890.  f@i  (1)  1855,  Isabella,  y.  d.  of  Rev.  Edward  Irving,  founder  of 
the  Irvingite  Church;  (2)  1875,  Miss  Bertha  Meriton  Corderv.  Resided  at 
Sevenoaks.    |B  23  Feb.,  1902.

of  Francis  Seymour,  below,  p.  78).

74  Winchester  College.  i  841-2 

[In  a  MS.  notebook  belonging  to  Dr.  Mobcrly,  in  which  he  was  accustomed  to  note 
the  names  of  those  to  whose  parents  he  had  promised  their  admission  as  Commoners,  there 
appears,  under  date  1841,  the  name — 

"  Stephenson,  son  of  James,  Esq.,  10,  New  Sq.,  Lincoln's  Inn,  Sept.,  1841,"  to  which 
he  has  subsequently  added  the  note  "abiit  ad  Cantab."  There  is,  however,  a  difficulty 
here,  for  the  University  Calendars  about  this  period  contain  only  the  following  Stephen- 
sons  : — 

(1)  Charles  ;  Pemb.  1846  ; 

(2)  Augustus  Frederick  William  Keppel ;  Caius  1844  ; 

(3)  John  Joseph  ;  Caius  1845  ; 

(4)  Cookson ;  Trin.  1851 ;  and 

(5)  Sussex  Vane  ;  Caius  1852  ; 

and  of  these  (1)  was  the  e.  s.  of  Charles  Stephenson,  Esq.  of  Croydon ;  (2)  and  (5)  were 
sons  of  Henry  Frederick  Stephenson,  Esq.,  Commissioner  of  Excise  ;  (3)  was  a  son  of 
Joseph  Stephenson,  Esq.,  of  the  Bank  of  Ireland  ;  and  (4)  was  the  son  of  Wm.  Stephenson, 
Esq.,  of  Holmforth.]

Univ.  Coll.  Oxon  1847,  Sch.  Exeter  Coll.  1848-60,  Fellow  1850-68,  and  again 
1885-93,  Hon.  Fellow  since  1893,  Tutor  1885-93,  2  CI.  1850,  B.A.  1853,  M.A. 
1854;  ||?.®.,  d  1852,  p  1853,  Classical  Moderator  in  Honours  1866-8,  1873, 
1878-9,  1882-4 ;  Curator  of  the  Taylor  Inst.  1869-93 ;  Fellow  of  the  British 
Academy ;  Corresponding  Member  of  Historical  Soc.  of  Greece,  and  of  the 
United  Armenian  Educational  Socs. ;  Hon.  Member  of  Parnassus  Philological 
Soc.  of  Athens  ;  Vice-Pres.  Soc.  for  Promoting  Hellenic  Studies  1890 ;  has 
travelled  extensively  in  Greece  and  in  European  and  Asiatic  Turkey  ;  author  of 
"The  Highlands  of  Turkey,"  2  vols.  1869,  "Lectures  on  the  Geography  of 
Greece"  1873,  "  Primer  of  Classical  Geography"  1877,  "  Turkish  Armenia  and 
Eastern  Asia  Minor  "  1881,  "  The  Church  and  the  Eastern  Empire  "  1888,  "  The 
Islands  of  the  Aegean"  1890,  "History  of  Ancient  Geography"  1897,  "An 
English  Commentary  on  Dante's  Divina  Commedia  "  1901 ;  editor  of  "  Finlay's 
History  of  Greece"  1877,  "Wordsworth's  Greece"  1882,  "Byron's  Childe 
Harold'"  1885,  "  Selections  from  Strabo  1893  ; "  contributor  to  the  EncyclopcBdia 
Britannica,  Journal  of  Hellenic  Studies,  Classical  Reinew,  the  Academi/,  and  other 
literary  periodicals.  fH  1868,  Augusta  Henrietta,  d.  of  Hans  David  Christopher 
Satow]  Esq.,  of  L^pper  Clapton.     Address  18,  Xorham  Gardens,  Oxford.

Seymour,  Arthur  Penrose,  b.  20  March,  1832,  s.  of  Kev.  George  Turner 
Seymour,  of  Freshwater,  and  Marianne  (nee  Billingsley),  his 
wife,  of  Ashwick  Grove,  Somerset. 
To  New  Zealand  1851 ;  sheep-farmer  for  about  30  years  at  Picton,  N.Z.  ;  now 
practising  as  a  land  survej'or,  licensed  surveyor  under  the  Land  Transfer  Act ; 
J. P.  for  New  Zealand  1856  ;  member  of  the  1st  Council  of  the  Province  of 
Marlborough  1860,  Superintendent  of  the  Province  1864-G,  re-elected  1870, 
and  held  the  jjost  of  Suiierintcndent  down  to  the  abolition  of  Provinces  in 
1877 ;  member  of  the  Legislative  Council  of  the  Colony  1865-72,  member  of 
the  House  of  Representatives  1872-5,  and  since  1876,  Chairman  of  Committees 
of  the  House  of  Representatives  1874-5,  and  1879-82  ;  paid  a  visit  to  England 
1875-6  ;  Chairman  of  Education  Board  1877,  annually  re-elected  down  to  1905, 
when  he  resigned  ;  member  of  the  1st  Board  of  Governors  of  the  "N'ictoria 
College,  N.Z.,  1898-1903;  over  40  years  a  member  of  the  Land  Board  of 
Marlborough  District ;  sole  Visiting  Justice  of  the  Picton  gaol  since  1877  ; 
for  many  years  at  different  times  Mayor  of  Picton.  f^  1856,  Catherine 
Florence,  2nd  d.  of  Frederick  lluddleston,  Esq.,  of  Nelson.  Address  Picton, 
N.Z.

Marshall,  Henry,  b.  22  April,  1831,  s.  of  George  Marshall,  Esq.,  of  Broad- 
water, Godalming,  and  Sarah,  his  wife,  3rd  d.  of  James 
Alexander,  Esq.,  of  Edenbridge,  Kent. 
Left  Easter  1848  for  a  solicitor's  office  ;  Cornet  17th  Lancers  1855,  Lieut.  1857, 
Capt.  1859  ;  exchanged  into  9th  Lancers  1860,  Major  1868,  Lieut.-Col.  1874, 
command  Cavalry  District,  Dorchester  1882,  Brevet-Col.  1879,  half  pay  1887  ; 
served  in  Crimea  Sept.,  1855,  to  April,  1856,  also  in  the  Indian  Mutiny  Campaign 
of  1857-9,  including  pursuit  of  Tautia  Topee  ;  in  command  of  the  9th  Lancers 
at  Sialkot  in  the  Punjab  when  the  Afghan  War  broke  out,  and  commanded 
them  on  the  march  to  Jellabad  in  the  Khyber  Pass  1877  (medal).    fH  18  Julj^, 
1860,  Alice,  d.    of  William  Heath  Jary,  Esq.,  of  Blofield  Lodge  and  Bur- 
lingham  House,  Norfolk  ;    resided  at  Newtown    Hill,  Newbury,  1891-1904. 
Address  14,  Holland  Rd.,  Brighton.

Law,  Thomas  Graves,  b.  4  Dec,  1836,  3rd  s.  of  Rev.  the  Hon  William  Towry 
Law,  V.  of  Harborne,  and  Chancellor  of  Bath  and  Wells, 
and    Hon.  Augusta   Graves,  his  wife,  4th  d.   of  Thomas 
North,  2nd  Lord  Grave?. 
Into  College  as  C.F,  Short  Half  1849 ;  left  Christmas  1851,  his  father  and  mother 
having  been  received  into  the  Catholic  Church ;  to  Stonj-hurst ;  then  to  Addis- 
combe  College  as  cadet  of  the  East  India  Co. ;  resigned  cadetship  1855  ;  entered 
the  London  Oratory  18  ISIarch,  1855,  ordained  Priest  29  Jan.,  1860  ;    seceded 
from  the  Catholic  Church  15  Nov.,  1878  ;  Librarian  Signet  Library,  Edinburgh, 
March,    1879-1904  ;    Hon.   LL,D.    Edinburgh   1898  ;    co-editor,    with    Canon 
Oakeley,  of  Haydock's  Douay  Bible ;  author  of  "  A  Calendar  of  the  English 
Martyrs"   1876,  "Conflicts  between  Jesuits  and   Seculars  under  Elizabeth" 
1889,  "Jesuits  in  the  Reign  of  Elizabeth"  1890;  editor  of  "The  Archpriest 
Controversy,"  2  vols.,  for  Camden  Societv,  1896-8,   "Archbishop  Hamilton's 
Catechism  1552,"  1884  ;  writer  in  the  D.N'.B.     fH  15  April,  1880,  Wilhelniina 
Frederica,  y.  d.  of  Capt.  John  James  Allen,  R.N.,  of  Errol  Park,  I'erthshire. 
33  12  March,  1904,  at  Woodlands,  Duddingston,  Midlothian,  N.B.  Cf.  Wyk.  ix. 
(n.  410)  93,  and  "  Collected  Essays  and  Reviews  of  Thomas  Graves  Law,  edited, 
Avith  a  Memoir,  by  P.  Hume  Brown,  LL.D.,"  1905.

1888  ;  Capt.  and  Hon.  Major  Staffs  Yeo.  Cav.  1883  ;  retired  1893  ;  J.P.  Middle- 
sex, Staffs.,  and  Worcs.     lifl  1899,  Harriet,  d.  of  Eev.  John  Bradney  Marsh, 
of   The    Lyde,    Staffs.      Address   Womburne    Wodehouse,    Wolverhampton.

Coope,  William  Jesser,  s.  of  Rev.  John  William  Coope,  E.  of  Falmouth. 

Ens.  57th  Regt.  1854,  Lieut.  1854,  Capt.  1856;  served  through  the  whole  of  the 
Crimean  Campaign  and  left  with  the  last  troops,  unwounded  ;  served  at  siege 
and  fall  of  Sebastopol,  and  at  the  Redan,  the  Quarries,  and  Kinbourn  ;  after 
the  repulse  at  the  Redan  18  June,  1855,  carried  despatches  from  Lord  West  to 
Lord  liaglan  across  the  open,  exposed  to  a  heavj-  fire,  and  afterwards  carried 


1850  Winchester  College.  123 

dcsi>atchcs  from  Lord  Raj^lan  to  Sir  George  Browne  (medal,  clasp,  and  Turkish 
medal)  ;  exchanged  into  7th  Regt.  1857,  and  into  Glth  Regt.  1863  ;  retired  on 
half  pay   1867;  Imperial  Ottoman  Gendarmerie  1877-80;    taken  prisoner. liy 
Gen.  Goiirko  in  one  of  the  outposts  of  Plevna  ;  commanded  Turkish  troops 
employed  in  construction  of  the  lines  Burjuk-Tchekmedjie  ;  raised  two  squadrons 
of  horse  in  Boer  War  1900-1,  one  of  which  (Brabant's  Regt.)  he  commanded 
at  siege  of  Wepener,  and  subsequent  operations  under  Gen.  Rundle  ;  in  charge 
of  Boer  prisoners  at  Diyatalawa,  Ceylon,  1901 ;  the  only  officer  who  served 
both  in  the  Crimea  and  in  the  Boer  War.

Kerb,  Henry  Schomberg  (f),  b.  15  Aug.,  1838,  2nd  s.  of  Rev.  Lord  Henry 
Francis  Charles  Kerr,  R.  of  Dittisham,  Devon,  and  Louisa 
Dorothea,  his  wife,  only  d.  of  Gen.  the  Hon.  Sir  Alexander 
Hope,  G.C.B. 
At  Glenalmond  Sept.  1848-50  ;  appointed  as  naval  cadet  to  H.M.S.  Vengeance 
15  July,  1852  ;  present  at  bombardment  of  Sebastopol  17  Oct.,  1854  ;  received 
into  the  Catholic  Church  at  Galashiels  22  Maj^,  1855  ;  appointed  to  II.M.S. 
Sphinx  June,  1855,  Black  Sea  ;  to  H.M.S.  Indus,  flagship,  N.  American  station, 
11  Dec,  1857  ;  Lieut.  1859  ;  to  H.IM.S.  Exmouth  April,  1859  ;  H.M.S.  Cyclopx 
August,  1859  ;  in  Indian  waters  down  to  spring  of  1861  ;  H.M.S.  Phaeton  on 
N.  American  and  W.  Indian  station  31  Oct.,  1861  ;  H.M.S.  Duncan,  flagship 
same  station,  July,  1864  ;  Acting  Commander  H.M.S.  Lily  20  Julj^,  1866 ; 
Commander  16  Nov.,  1866  ;  to  Paris  and  Rome  Feb.-April,  1867  ;  Commander 
H.M.S.  Bellerophon  May,  1867  ;  left  5  June,  1867  ;  entered  the  Novitiate  of 
the  Society  of  Jesus  at  Manresa,  Roehampton,  8  Sept.,  1867  ;  began  philosophy 
at  Stonyhurst  Sept.,  1870  ;  at  Mount  St.  Mary's  College,  Chesterfield,  1871-2  ; 
placed  on  retired  list,  R.N.  ;  to  St.  Beuno's  Coll.,  N.  Wales,  1872  ;  ordained 
priest  by  Dr.  Brown,  Bishop  of  Shrewsbury,  19  Sept.,  1875;  Minister  at 
Beaumont  Coll.,  near  Windsor,  1875-7  ;  attached  to  the  Mission  at  Garnet  Hill, 
Glasgow,  1877-8 ;  arrived  at  Cyprus  1  Feb.,  1879  ;  appointed  Chaplain  to  the 
Forces  4  Feb.,  1879  ;  opened  a  school  at  Liniassol  for  Cypriots,  which  had  a 
very  brief  career ;  in  Palestine  Jan.-May,  1880  ;  Chaplain  to  the  Marquis  of 
Ripon  when  Viceroy  of  India  1880-4  ;  at  Farm  St.,  Berkeley  Sq.,  London, 
Jan.-Oct.,  1885  ;  Roehampton  1886  ;  Holy  Name,  Manchester,  1886-8  ;  offered 
but  declined  Archbishopric  of  Bombay  1886 ;  Bournemouth  May-Dec,  1888  ; 
appointed  Superior  of  Zambesi  Mission  Dec,  1888  ;  arrived  in  S.  Africa  28 
March,  1889.  S  at  Grahamstown,  18  Aug.,  1895.  Cf.  "Henry  Schomberg 
Kerr,  Sailor  and  Jesuit,"  1901,  by  the  Hon.  Mrs.  ]Max well-Scott.

Hearn,  Francis   George,  b.  10  Jan.,  1841,  bro.  of  Thomas  John,  William, 

Charles  Shuckburgh,  and  Risley  Verney,  above,  pp.  54,  72, 

78,  117. 
Ens.  Bengal  Staff  Corps  1859,  Lieut.  3rd  Bengal  N.I.  1860,  to  17th  Bengal  N.I. 

1863,  subsequently  Adjut. ;  served  with  29th  Bengal  N.I.  in  Bhootan  expedition, 
and  took  part  in  storming  of  Dewangiri ;  Assist.  Commander  Jullandur  May, 
1 865  ;  Brunnoo,  Punjab,  1865.  13  of  fever  10  June,  1866,  at  Shaik  Boodeen,  a 
hill  station  near  Brunnoo.  The  Government  of  the  Punjab,  in  reporting  his 
death  to  the  Government  of  India,  said:  "The  deceased  was  a  young  officer 
of  unusually  high  promise.  His  death,  it  is  feared,  was  accelerated  by  his 
conscientious  devotion  to  his  duties,  from  which  he  could  not  be  persuaded 
entirely  to  withdraw,  even  after  he  had  been  attacked  by  fever,  and  his  loss 
will  be  deeply  lamented  bj'  all  with  whom  he  was  associated."

DE  Sausmarez,  Philip  Algernon  (f)  (in  the  Register  Saumarez),  b.  22  April,

Sausmarez,  R.N.,  and  Jane  Maria  {nee  Barlow),  his  wife. 

Left  1857  ;  joined  the  Mercantile  Marine  1858,  commanded  African  Royal  Mail 

Steamers  1869-71  ;  resided  in  Trinidad  1872-6  ;  settled  in  Birkenhead  1878  ;

Acting-Consul  in  1899.    iH  18  March,  1869,  Maria  Louisa,  d.  of  Thomas  J. 

Gould,  Esq.,  of  Port  of  Spain,  Trinidad,  W.I.     Address  Bracon  Yilla,  Moreton, 

near  Birkenhead.

and   Elizabeth    Anne,   his  wife,   d.   of    R  chard    Edensor

Superannuated ;  went  into  Commoners  as  a  prefect  1861  ;  Ens.  37th  Regt.  1863, 
Lieut.  1865,  Adjut.  1866,  Capt.  1868,  A.D.C.  to  Major-Gen.  Beatson  1868-70, 
D.A.Q.M.G.  Bengal  1872-3 ;  into  3rd  Dragoon  Guards  1873  ;    Staff  College 
1877-8  ;  Stud.  Inner  T.  1877  ;  Brigade-Major  of  Cavalry  in  Natal  1879,  Zulu  War 
(despatches,  medal  with  clasp,  Brevet- Alaj or)   1879,  Principal  Staff  Officer 
Transvaal  Field  Force  1879-80,  Military  Sec.  to  Sir  Garnet  (afterwards  Lord) 
Wolseley  in  S.  Africa  1880,  Brevet  Lieut.-Col.  1880  ;  Chief  Staff  Officer  to  Sir 
Pomeroy  CoUey,  Boer  War ;  present  at  Majuba,  made  prisoner  28  Feb.,  1881, 
released  end  of  March  ;  Major  ;  A.A.G.  Cavalry  Division  Egyptian  Campaign 
(thrice  mentioned  in   despatches,  medal,  clasp,  bronze   star,  3rd   Osmanieh, 
Brevet-Col.,  C.B.,  A.D.C.  to  the  Queen)  1881 ;  A.D.C.  to  Lord  Spencer  in 
Ireland  1882-4 ;  Brigadier  Suakin  Field  Force  (present  at  El  Teb,  relief  of 
Tokar,  Tamai,  and  advance  to  Tananeb  (despatches,  two  clasps,  K.C.B.)  1884; 
Brigadier  Khartoum  Relief  Expedition  1884  ;  mortally  wounded  at  Abu  Klea 
19  Jan.,  1885  ;  Major-Gen.  for  distinguished  service  1885.    f$t  19  Dec,  1877, 
Georgiana  Janet,  d.  of  Admiral  Sir  James  Stirling,  and  widow  of  Major-Gen. 
Sir  II.  Tombs,  V.C.    M  16  Feb.,  1885.     See  D.N.B.  liv.  291.     Lord  Wolseley, 
in  telegraphing    his  death  to   England,  said,  "No  braver  soldier  or  more 
brilliant  leader  of  men  ever  wore  the  Queen's  uniform."    Memorial  gateway  at 
Winchester  1886.    Memorial  panel  in  St.  Paul's  Cathedral  1889.

1869-85  ;  Fellow  of  Oriel  Coll.,  and  Oriel  Prof,  of  Interpretation  in  Univ.  of

B.N.C.  Oxon  1891  ;  Visitor  of  St.  Boniface's  Coll.,  Warminster,  and  Salisbury

Koman  Conquest  of  Southern  Britain"  1889,  "Bishop's  Palace,  Salisbury"

Surrey.     Club  Constitutional.

Address  Craig  Lodge,  Tarbert,  N.B.

Vienna,  Leipzig,  and  Dresden  ;  Trcas.  and  Ex-Pres.  Obst.  Soc.,  London  (late

Roy.  Saxon  Lying-in  Hospital,  Dresden ;   author  of    various  papers  in  the

walking  alone  near  Grindelwald,  Switzerland,  4  Sept.,  1881.    Cf.  Sol.  Jo.  xxv. 

850  ;  and  for  some  verses  in  his  memory  see  Wyk.  iv.  (n.  164)  60.

Makuiott,  Charles  (B),  b.  14  Oct.,  1848  (2nd  s.),  bro.  of  the  next.

Parallel  Psalter,"  2nd  ed.  1904  ;  joint-editor  of  "  The  Holy  Bible,  with  various

Banbury,  Frederick  George  (B),  b.  2  Dec,  1850,  e.  s.  of  Frederick  Banburj',

206,  216,  278). 
Member  of  the  Stock  Exchange  1872  (Messrs.  Fredk.  Banbury  &  Sons) ;  Trustee 
and  Manager  Stock  Exchange ;  J. P.  Huntingdonshire ;  M.P.  (C.)  for  Peckham 
Division,  Camberwell  1892-1905  ;  unsuccessful  Candidate  1906  ;  Director  Great 
Northern  Railway;  created  Ist  Bart.  1902;  M.P.  City  of  London  1906.    ffl

St.  John's  Coll.  Camb.  1872,  B.A.  1876 ;  entered  Foreign  Office  1877,  Acting  3rd 
Secretary  1880,  employed  at  Constantinople ;  appointed  to  assist  the  British 
Agent  on  the  Behring  Sea  Arbitration  at  Paris  1892  ;  Private  Secretary  to  Sir 
T.  H.  Sanderson  1894-6  ;  Assistant  Clerk  1896  ;  Secretary  to  the  British  Pleni- 
potentiaries at  the  Peace  Conference  at  the  Hague,  and  Acting  Secretary  of

The  Rev.  George  Moberly,  D.C.L.,  having  been  elected  Fellow  of  Winchester 
College,  resigned  the  Head  Mastership,  the  resignation  to  take  effect  at  the  end 
of  this  Half  Year.  The  Rev.  George  Ridding,  D.D.,  was  elected  Head  Master 
27  Sept.,  1866.

Major  (retired)  1895  ;  promoted  Lieut.-Col.  in  the  Reserve  1902  for  services  in 

connection  with  South  African  War  1899-1902  ;  started  a  co-operative  society 

in  1894,  which  developed  into  the  Canteen  and  Mess  Co-operative  Society, 

which  in  1905  was  doing  a  business  of  £300,000  a  year ;  started  the  People's 

Refreshment  House  Association  1896  ;  one  of  the  chief  promoters  of  Central 

Public  House  Trust  Association  1900.    IB  suddenly  at  Witlev,  Worthing,  29 

June,  1905.    See  Obituary  Notice,  Times,  22  July,  1905.

CaosSE,  Hekbebt  Lewis  (D),  b.  8  June,  1856,  bro.  of  Thomas  Warren,  above, 
p.  204. 
Left  April,  1874 ;  Solicitor  1879,  practising  in  Wigmore  St.,  Londou ;  a  convert  to 
the  Konmn  Catholic  Church  1880  ;  entered  the  Order  of  St.  Dominic  1882,  took 
the  name  of  Aloysius,  studied  at  Louvain,  received  Minor  Orders  1886,  ordained 
Sub-Deacon,  and  Deacon  in  1887,  ordained  Priest  by  Bishop  Anthonis  at  Louvain 
in  March,  1888 ;  for  twelve  years  (1890-1902)  Rector  of  the  College  for  the 
education  of  boys  for  the  Dominican  Order,  first  at  Hinckley,  and  then  at 
Hawkesyard,  Rugelcy ;  received  the  degree  of  S.T.D.  from  the  Master-General 
of  the  Order  1900 ;  at  St.  Peter's  Priory,  Hinckley  1902-5 ;  in  charge  of  the 
Mission  at  Heron's  Ghyll  since  1905.  Address  Kev.  Aloysius  Crosse,  O.P., 
Catholic  Church,  Heron's  Ghyll,  near  Uckfield,  Sussex.

Sub-Lieut  Royal  Wilts.  Militia  1872  ;  2nd  Lieut.  Cth  Dragoou  Guards  1878  ;   served 
in  Afghan  War  1879-80,  with  Khyber  Div.  Cabul  Field  Force  (despatches,

Col.  Commanding  1st  Wilts.  Royal  Vols.  1900-3  ;  took  name  of  Chaloner,  under 
will  of  late  Admiral  Chaloner,  by  Royal  Licence  1888 ;  M.P.  (C.)  Westbury 
Div.,  Wilts.   1895-1900;  J.P.  Wilts,  and  N.R.  Yorks.      M  1882,  Margaret,

Benson,  Francis  Eobert  (A),  b.  4  Nov.,  1858,  bro.  of  William  Arthur  Smith 
and  Cecil  Foster,  above,  pp.  236,  261,  atd  of  Godfrey  Eath- 
bone,  below,  p.  343. 
New  Coll.  Oxon  1878 ;  Winner  of  the  Inter  Tarsity  three  miles ;  revived 
the  Greek  Drama  in  England  by  producing  the  Agamemnon  of  ^.schylus  at 
Oxford,  in  which  he  played  "  Clyt.minestra,"  1880;  played  ,"  Paris"  in 
Romeo  and  Juliet  at  the  Lyceum  Theatre  1882  ;  produced  the  Agamemnon  at 
Winchester,  Harrow,  Eton,  and  St.  George's  Hall,  London  ;  founder  of  the 
Shakespearean  Companies  that  bear  his  name ;  Lessee  of  the  Globe  Theatre, 
London,  Dec,  1889,  to  April,  1890,  reviving  Shakespearean  plays,  including 
A  Midsummer  Night's  Dream;  Lessee  of  Lyceum  Theatre  1900  {Richard  II., 
Henry  V.,  The  Tempest,  Hamlet);  of  the  Comedy  Theatre  1900-1  (eight 
Shakespearean  plays)  ;  has  conducted  sixteen  Memorial  Festivals  at 
Stratford-on-Avon,  producing  in  1905  fifteen  different  Shakespearean  plays, 
and  Marlowe's  Sdwa rd  / 1. ;  Life  Trustee  of  Shakespeare's  Birthplace  1900. 
IE  188*;,  Gertrude,  d.  of  Capt.  Samwell,  of  the  48th  iRogt.  Addresses  11, 
Henrietta  St.,  Covent  Garden,  W.C. ;  and  Elmhurst,  Goring,  Oxon.

Gore,  St.  John  Corbet  (H),  b.  10  Dec,  1859,  s.  of  Ralph  Thomas  Gore,  Esq. 

(who  died  1860),  and  Isabella  Jane,  his  wife,  d.  of  William 

Hopkins,  of  Frayne,  Meath. 
From  Elizabeth  Coll.,  Guernsey  ;  R.M.C.  Sandhurst ;  2nfl  Lieut.  19th  Hussars  1879, 
exchanged  into  5th  Dragoon  Guards  1879,  Lieut.  1881,  Capt.  1885,  served  with 
Camel  Corps  in  Soudan  Expedition  1884-5  (medal  with  clasp  and  bronze  star), 
Major  1893,  Lieut.-Col.  1899  ;  Assist.  Military  Sec.  to  Lieut.-Gen.  Sir  Baker 
Kussell,  G.C.B.,  and  Lieut.-Gen.  Sir  George  Luck,  K.C.B.,  1897-9  ;  served  in 
South  African  War  1899-1902,  battles  of  Elandslaagte  and  Lombard's  Kop,  siege 
of  Ladysmith  (twice  mentioned  in  despatches,  medal  with  four  cl-Tsps,  King's 
medal  with  two  clasps) ;  Brevet-Col.  (half-pay)  1903  ;  C.B.  1901 ;  author  of

Smith,  Arthur  Hamilton  (f),  b.  2  Oct.,  1860,  bro.  of  James  Parker,  above, 
p.  230,  and  of  George  Edward,  below,  p.  411. 
I.C.S.,  but  renounced  ;  Trin.  Coll.  Camb.  1879,  1  CI.  1883,  B.A.  1884,  M.A.  1888; 
F.S.A. ;  has  examined  in  Honours  Schools,  Cambridge,  Oxford,  and   Edin- 
burgh ;   excavated  in   Cj'prus   for  British   Museum    1893-4,    1896  ;   formerly 
editor  of  Journal  of  Hellenic   Studies;  Hon.  Librarian  of   Hellenic  Society; 
Hon.  Treasurer  British  School  at  Rome ;  Member  of  German  Archaeological 
Institute ;  Assist.  Keeper  of  Department  of   Greek   and   Roman  Antiquities, 
*  British  Museum,  1904  ;  author  of  "  Guide  to  Department  of  Greek  and  Roman 

Antiquities,  British  Museum,"  "  Catalogue  of  Engraved  Gems  in  British 
IMuseum,"  "  Catalogue  of  Sculpture  in  British  Museum,"  Catalogues  of  Lans- 
downc,  Yarborough,  and  Wobum  Abbey  Collections,  "  White  Athenian  A'ases 
in]  British  Museum "  (this  work  is  illustrated  by  the  Cyclograph,  his  own 
invention,  awarded  a  gold  medal  at  Berlin  Photographic  Exhibition,  1896). 
M  1897,  Gertrude,  e.  d.  of  Rev.  Preb.  Blomfield  Jackson.  Address  22, 
Endsleigh  St.,  W.C.

football  for  England  1883-7  ;  Head  Master  of  Loretto  School  since  1903.     fjl 

1903,  Emmeline,  d.  of  the  late  Robert  Worrall,  Esq.    Address  Loretto,  Mussel- 

burgli,  N.B.     Clubs  Athenaeum,  Primrose.

HoGAETH,  David  George  (G),  b.  23  May,  1862,  s.  of  Rev.  George  Hogarth, 
V.  of  Barton-on-Humber,  Lines.,  and  Jane  Elizabeth,  his 
wife,  e.  d.  of  J.  Uppleby,  Esq.,  of  Scarborough. 
Demy  Magd.  Coll.  Oxon,  1  CI.  Mod.  1882,  1  CI.  B.A.  1885,  Craven  Fellow  1886, 
Fellow  and  Tutor  of  Magd.  Coll.   1888-93 ;  explored  Asia  Minor  1887,   1890, 
1891,    1894 ;    excavated    at   Paphos  in   Cyprus   1888 ;    appointed   by   Egypt 
Exploration  Fund  1893,  and  excavated  Temple  of  Der-el-Bahari  at  Thebes, 
also   at  Alexandria   1895 ;    in   Fayun    1896  ;    Special  Correspondent  for  the 
rj?nes  in  Crete  and  Thessaly  1897;    Director  British  School  at  Athens  189<- 
1900  ;  Director  Cretan  Exploration  Fund  since  1899  ;  conducted  excavations  at 
Knosos  and  Dictaean  Cave  1900,  and  at  Zakro  1901 ;  Member  of  British  Academy 
1905  ;  author  of  "  Devia  Cypria  "  1890,  "  Modern  and  Ancient  Roads  in  Eastern 
Asia  Minor"  1892,  "A  Wandering  Scholar  in  the  Levant"  1896,  "Philip  and 
Alexander  of   Macedon"  1897,    "The  Nearer  East"  1902,  "The  Penetration 
of  Arabia"  1904;    editor  and  part-author  of  "Authority  and  Archajology  " 
1899  ;  editor  of  "  Echoes  from  the  Oxford  Magazine"  1890,  "More  Echoes" 
1897,  and  the  Acting  Edition  of  the  Frogs  of  Aristophanes  1892.     iJH  7  Nov., 
1894,  Laura  Violet,  y.  d.  of  George  Charles  Uppleby,  Esq.,  of  Barrow  Hall. 
Address  Chapel  Meadow,  Forest  Row.     Club  Savile.

Robert  William  Keate,  Esq.,  Governor  and  Commander-in-

Winchfield. 
R.M.C.  Sandhurst ;  2nd  Lieut.  Ist  Batt.  Duke  of  Cornwall's  L.I.  (32ud  Regt.)  1831, 
then   Leicester   Regt.   1881  ;    Madras   S.C.   1883 ;    Wing   Officer  4th  Madras

NoBKis,  Francis  Lushingtox  (f),  b.  1  Sept.,  1864,  s.  of  Rev.  John  Pilkington 
Norris,  Canon  of  Bristol  (Archdeacon  of  Bristol  1881). 
TriQ.  Coll.  Camb.  1883,  2  CI.  B.A.  1886,  M.A.  1890  ;  Wells  Tlieol.  Coll. ;  1^.©., 
d  1887,  p  1888,  C.  Tewkesbury  1887-9  ;  Missionary  at  Peking  1889-91,"  Yung 
Ching  1891-4,  Tientsin  1894-9,  S.P.G.  Missionary  at  Peking  since  1900,  and 
Exam.  Chnpl.  to  Bishop  of  North  China  since  1889.  "  He  superintended, 
often  under  heavy  fire,  the  construction  of  defences  in  the  Princes  Fu,  and  in 
other  exposed  places,  working  always  with  a  courage  and  energy  worthy  of 
admiration.  He  was  struck  in  the  neck  once  by  a  segment  of  a  shell,  but 
escaped  marvellouslj'  from  serious  injury.  He  speaks  Chinese  well,  and 
Chinese  worked  under  him  with  a  fearlessness  that  few  men  can  inspire." 
— The  Times,  15  Oct.,  1900.  He  was  offered,  but  refused,  a  3rd-clas3  Button 
for  his  services  on  the  occasion  of  the  Boxer  rising.  Address  Church  of 
England  Mission,  Peking,  China.

Dent,  Cecil  Wynter  (F),  b.  28  March,  1869  (3rd  s.),  bro.  of  Ernest  Freshfield,

Left  Easter,  1888  ;  with  Messrs.  Frith,  Sands  &  Co.,  merchants,  50,  Old  Broad  St., 
E.C.,  1888-91 ;  Clerk  in  the  Bank  of  England  1891-1902  ;  served  in  South  Africa 
with  Imperial  Yeomanry  (Paget's  Horse)  1900-1902  ;  given  a  commission  1901 ; 
retired  1902 ;  went  back  to  South  Africa  1903,  and  entered  Civil  Service  at 
Bloemfontein ;  placed  on  the  permanent  staff  1904.  Address  in  South  Africa 
United  Service  Club,  Bloemfontein.  Address  in  England  Hunsingore, 
Wetherby,  Yorks.     Club  Isthmian.

relief  of  Pekin  and  Tientsin  1900  (medal  and  clasp) ;  retired  with  a  pension 

March,  1905  ;  succeeded  his  brother  at  Caerynwch  Jan.,  1905  ;  J.P.  Merioneth 

1905.      Address  Caerynwch,    Dolgelly:      Clubs  Naval    and    Military,   Junior 

Constitutional.

Wybebgh,  Wilfeid  John  (f),  b.  16  July,  1868,  s.  of  ll.-v.  Christopher  Wybergh, 
R.  of  Scrayingliam,  Yorks. 
Left  1887 ;  to  School  of  Miucs,  Freiberg,  Saxouy ;  an  early  pioneer  of  Rhodesia 
1891,  and  Engineer  to  various  mining  companies  ;  went  to  Johannesburg,  and 
became  Engineer  to  the  Consolidated  Goldfields  of  South  Africa,  Ltd.,  1894 ; 
President  South  African  League  1898 ;  retired  from  professional  work  1899 ; 
organized  petition  of  Transviial  British  subjects  to  the  Queen  1899  ;  served  as 
Intelligence  Officer  during  the  War,  and  after  the  annexation  of  the  Transvaal 
in  an  administrative  capacity  under  military  administration,  until  appointed 
Commissioner  of  Mines  and  Member  of  Executive  and  Legislative  Councils, 
Transvaal;  resigned  these  posts  Nov.,  1903;  M.L.A.  (Nationalist)  for 
Marshallstown,  Johannesburg,  1907 ;  author  of  various  technical  and  scientific 
papers.  fH  S  Dec,  1893,  Katharine  Emily,  e.  d.  of  S.  Jardine  Windowe,  Esq., 
M.D.,  Deputy  Surgeon-Gen.  Madras  Medical  Service.  Addresn  Johannesburg. 
Clubs  Rand  and  New  (Johannesburg).

Moobe,  Walter  (E),  b.  14  Oct.,  1871  (y.  s.),  bro.  of  William  Maxwell  Scolt, 
above,  p.  430. 
Civil  Engineer  employed  on  construction  of  northern  extension  of  Central 
Uruguay  Railway  1889-92 ;  on  construction  of  Rock  Island  Railway,  Texas, 
U.S.A.  1892-  3  ;  returned  to  Ireland  1894,  and  went  to  South  Africa,  becoming 
Surveyor  to  New  Primrose  Co.  group  of  mines  on  the  Rand ;  returned  to 
Ireland  1899,  and  then  went  to  Klondyke  as  mining  expert,  returning  Nov., 
1899  ;  joined  the  Duke  of  Cambridge's  Own  Imperial  Yeomanry  as  trooper; 
taken  prisoner  at  Lindley  and  detained  three  months ;  served  with  short 
periods  with  Royal  Engineers  and  Northumberland  Fusiliers,  and  finallv  as 
transport  officer  to  Col.  Gowinge's  flving  column  ;  wounded.  JB  in  hospital 
at  Burghersdorp,  6  Nov.,  1901.     See  AVyk.  viii.  (n.  388)  371. 

Pattenson,  Edward  Cooke  Tylden-  (B),  b.  10  Dec,  1871,  bro.  of  William 

Boys,  above,  p.  253. 

B.M.A.  Woolwich  1889 ;  2nd  Lieut.  R.E.,  Lieut.  1895,  Capt.  1903 ;   1st  Sappers 

and  Miners,  Roorkee,  India  ;  served  with  Chitral  Relief  Force  1895,  including 

Malakand  Pass  (medal  with  clasp) ;  on  N.W.  Frontier  of  India  1897-8  (clasp), 

and  on  China  Expedition  1900  (despatches).

District  Officer,  Kuantan,  Pahang,  F.M.S.  1900-3  ;  seconded  for  service  under 

the  Siamese  Government,  as  Assist.  Adviser  to  H.H.  the  Raja  of  Kelantan 

1903  ;  4th-Class  Royal  Siamese  Order  of  the  Crown  1905  ;  resigned  the  Civil 

Service  of  the  F.M.S.  and  joined  the  Siamese  Civil  Service  1906.    Address 

Bangkoli.     Club  Sports.

Anderson,  Dunlop  (A),  b.  21  June,  1878,  e.  s.  of  John  Anderson,  Esq.,  M.D.,

of  J.  Usher  Dunlop,  Esq.,  of  Edinburgh  (bro.  of  Archie 

Eipon,  below,  p.  554). 

Studied  mining  engineering  in  British  Columbia  and  Canada ;    served  in  South 

African  War  in  South  African  Light  Horse,  then  as  2nd  Lieut,  Imperial 

Yeomanry  ;  promoted  to  Lieut,  for  meritorious  conduct  in  the  field ;  serving  in 

Uganda,  in  Colonial  Civil  Service,  since  May,  1903.   Address  Entebbe,  Uganda, 

East  Africa.    Home  address  9,  Harley  St.,  W.

MoNSON,  Charles  Evelyn  John  (D),  b,  4  May,  1878,  2nd  s.  of  Eev,  the  Hon. 

Evelyn  John  Monson,  E.  of  Croft  (d.  13  Sept.,  1892),  and 

Anne  Grace   Hynde,  his  wife,  of  Stainfield  House,  near 

Wragby,  Lincoln,  d.  of  James  Kinnear,  Esq.,  of  Edinburgh. 

Left  July,  1895  ;  Land  Agent  in  Nottinghamshire  1897-1903 ;  farming  and  trading 

in  the  Transvaal   since  April,  1903.    Address  Leener  Kraal,  near  Haman's 

Kraal,  Pretoria  North,  South  Africa. 

Turner,  Ealph  Beresford  (I),  b.  17  March,  1879,  s.  of  Edward  John  Turner, 

Esq.,  above,  p.  16,  and  bro.  of  Arthur  Edward,  Ernest  Vere, 

and  John  Maurice,  above,  pp.  450,  462,  468,  and  of  Arnold 

Geoffrey  and  Denis  Shewcll,  below,  pp.  534,  572. 

Left   1895 ;  farming  in  Orange  Free  State  and  trading  in  Basutoland   1895-9 ; 

served  through  the  siege  of  Ladysmith,  being  attached  as  Temporary  Lieut,  to 

23rd  Company  R.E,,  also  Director  of  Traffic  and  Commissariat  Officer;  he 

subsequently  served  under  Col,  Rawlinson    and  Gen,  Sir  Ian  Hamilton  as 

Telegraph  Officer,  and  was  attached  to  the  Military  Telegraphs  in  Pretoria ; 

Officer  Commanding  blockhouses  for  two  months  ;  Manager  of  a  Government 

horse-breeding  farm  in  Transvaal  1902-3;    farming  in  Transvaal  with  his 

brother  (D,  S.  Turner)  since  beginning  of  1904.     Address  Clifton,  Ermelo, 

Transvaal,  South  Africa.

George  James,  9th  Earl  of  Carlisle. 

Nicholas,  Wilfred  Lawbance  John  (K),  b.  15  Dec,  1891,  s.  of  W.  H. 
Nicholas,  Esq.,  Durban  High  School,  Natal. 

Pain,  Nigel  Squaeey  (A),  b.  7  May,  1892,  s.  of  Coard  Squarey  Pain,  Esq., 
above,  p.  210,  and  bro.  of  Coard  Henry,  above,  p.  597. 
Address  Bebington,  Birkenhead.

above,  p.  306. 
Address  Brookheath,  Breamore,  Hants.

Parr,  above,  p.  210,  and  bro.  of  John  Willoughby,  above, 
p.  621.

Esq.,  Glanyrafon,  Bedford.

ADDENDA  ET   CORRIGENDA. 

p.  42.    Randall,  R.  W.     13  at  Pelham,  Bournemouth,  23  Deo.,  1906. 

p.  47.  Dewar,  D.  E.  For  "  Amyela  "  read  "  Amycla."  Add  ©  at  99,  London 
Road,  St.  Leonards-on-Sea,  30  Dec,  1906. 

p.  51.    Pell,  B.  H.  St.  J.    S  14  Feb.,  1907. 

p.  79.    Kendall,  F.    S  ]  4  March,  1907. 

p.  81.     Barnard,  R.  C.    IB  12  Dec,  1906. 

p.  89.    Johnson,  A.  B.    Q  7  Feb.,  1907. 

p.  89.  Nevill,  W,  a.  (2nd  s.).  At  Marlborough  Coll.  Aug.,  1843,  to  July, 
1844;  into  Bank  of  England.  Q  at  Blackheath  Hill  12  or  13  Dec,  1853.  See 
Gentleman's  Magazine  (N.S.),  xli.  Ill,  218. 

p.  92.  Bramston,  J.  Registrar  of  the  Order  of  St.  Michael  and  St.  George 
1892-1907. 

p.  100.  Currie,  L.  D.  H.  ©  3  Jan.,  1907.  See  Obituary  Notice  in  the  Timet 
for  4  Jan.,  1907. 

p.  100.     Egerton,  0.  C.     J3  27  Jan.,  1907. 

p.  106.    Elderton.     JFor  "  Ist "  read  "  2nd." 

p.  112.     Ehot,  W.  K.     From  Marlborough  Coll. 

p.  134.     AwDUT,  T.     D  20  May,  1907. 

p.  138.    Trevilian,  J.  R.    J.P.  Essex. 

p.  169.  Between  the  names  of  Stanbridge  and  Wigram  the  following  entry  has 
been  by  an  oversight  omitted  : — 

Stewart,  Montgomery  Granville,  b.  19  Jan.,  1844,  7th  s.  of  James  Stewart, 

Esq.,  J.P.,  D.L.,  of  Cairnsmore,  Kirkcudbright,  and   Elizabeth,  his 

wife,  only  d.  of  Gilbert  MacLeod,  Esq.,  M.D.,  of  Gloucester  Place, 

London. 

Into  the  house  of  Messrs.  T.  and  J.  Brocklebank,  Liverpool ;  then  in  business  in 

Calcutta.    fSi  Eliza  Clare  Hume  Smith.    ©  13  Maj-,  1882. 

p.  183.  Between  the  names  of  Thompson  and  Williams  the  following  entry 
should  be  inserted  : — 

Tdck,  Albert  Hustler  (B),  b.  28,  July,  1848,  s.  of  Charles  Edward  Tuck,  Esq., 
solicitor,  of  Norwich,  and  cousin  of  J.  J.  Tuck,  above,  p.  167. 
Left  Midsummer,  1865  ;  Royal  Agricultural  Coll.  Cirencester  1866-8,  Scholarship 
and  Diploma ;  learnt  land-agent's  business  on  the  Edenhall  Estate,  Cumber- 
land ;  land  agent  and  farmer  in  Norfolk  and  elsewhere.    fR  1876, ,  d.  of 

George  Lamb,  Esq.,  agent  for  the  Lowther  estates  to  Lord  Lonsdale.    Address 
Coney  Weston  Lodge,  Suffolk.

de  rinstruction  Publique  "  of  France  1907.

"Dictionary  of  French  and  Italian  Quotations"  1900,  "History  of  the  45th  Eegi- 
ment "  1902. 

p.  298.     Haverfield,  F.  J.     Camden  Professor  of  Ancient  History  1907. 

p.  350.  Shirley,  W.  K.  Pupil  of  Basil  Chanpneys,  Esq.,  1888-92,  Ist  Medal 
Architectural  Association,  and  Silver  Medal  for  essay  at  R.I.B.A.  1894. 

p.  507.  Between  the  names  of  Lyon  and  Malan  the  following  entry  has  been 
by  an  oversight  omitted : — 

Mackey,  Hugh  James  Alexander  (F),  b.  19  March,  1876,  s.  of  the  late  Capt. 

Hugh  Allen  Mackey,  E.A.,  and  Adelaide,  his  wife,  d.  of  the  late 

James  Eraser,  Esq.,  and  stepson  of  Col.  Herbert  Locock,  C.B.,  E.E., 

26,  Queen's  Gate  Gardens,  S.W. 

Left  1893 ;  R.M.A.  Woolwich ;  2nd  Lieut.  R.F.A.  1899,  Lieut.  1899,  Capt.  1902 ; 

M.V.O.  (5th  class)  1901.    Address  as  above. 

p.  531.  ZiMMERN,  A.  E.  Translator  of  Guglielmo  Ferrero's  "  The  Greatness 
and  Decline  of  Rome"  1907. 

p.  572.  Between  the  names  of  Brooke  and  Cheesman  the  following  entry  should 
be  inserted : — 

Cabb,  Percy  Wykeham  King  (F),  b.  18  Oct.,  1884,  s.  of  Lieut.-Col.  Edward 
Elliott  Oarr,  C.B.,Timperley  House,  Leamington,  and  Rosa  Elizabeth, 
his  wife,  e.  d.  of  Rev.  A.  Hall. 
Left  July,  1899 ;  K.M.C.  Sandhurst ;  2nd  Lieut.  2nd  Batt.  Seaforth  Highlanders 
1905.

Frimley,  Camberley.
